Description: Daimler AG and three of its subsidiaries resolved charges related to a Foreign Corrupt Practices Act investigation into the company's worldwide sales practices. Daimler AG's Russian subsidiary DaimlerChrysler Automotive Russia SAO, subsequently renamed Mercedes-Benz Russia SAO, and its German subsidiary, Export and Trade Finance GmbH, each pleaded guilty to criminal charges. Daimler AG entered into a deferred prosecution agreement as did its Chinese subsidiary.

The U.S. Department of Labor's Wage and Hour Division and Mercedes-Benz announced that the company agreed to pay 240 workers at its Vance, Ala., plant $687,588 in back wages for the period Feb. 18, 2001 to Feb. 9, 2003. Mercedes paid the back wages as a result of a self-audit it conducted after the Wage and Hour Division brought to the company's attention allegations that it had not properly paid paint department employees for required uniform changing time.
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Description: Mercedes-Benz USA and its parent corporation DaimlerChrysler AG agreed to pay $1.2 million in civil penalties to resolve allegations that they violated the Clean Air Act by failing to promptly notify the Environmental Protection Agency about defects in the air pollution controls installed on numerous 1998 to 2006 Mercedes model vehicles.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Private Litigation Case Title: Ledbetter et al v. Mercedes Benz U.S. International, Inc.

Description: NHTSA signed a $20 million settlement agreement with Mercedes Benz USA to resolve Audit Query 18-004, which was opened in 2018 to investigate the company's recall reporting and recall execution practices.

The U.S. Department of Justice, Environmental Protection Agency, and California Air Resources Board announced a $1.5 billion settlement with German automaker Daimler AG and its American subsidiary Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC resolving alleged violations of the Clean Air Act and California law associated with emissions cheating. The settlement included $945 million in penalties and $534 million to extend vehicle warranties and to pay for mitigation projects.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Info Source: List of FY2003 ADEM Administrative Orders obtained via an open records request on October 5, 2020.

Agency: South Coast (CA) Air Quality Management District

Description: Mercedes-Benz agreed to an settlement worth an estimated $700 million to resolve class action litigation concerning the sale of vehicles with emissions-cheating software.
Mercedes-Benz agreed to a $32 million settlement of class action litigation brought by car owners who said they weren't warned that non-synthetic motor oil could cause premature engine wear.

NAICS Translation: 423120: Motor Vehicle Supplies and New Parts Merchant Wholesalers
